text:
I use HARO for both pitching and for my writing. You always get some completely irrelevant answers, but there is a button to click “This pitch is not relevant”. I get very trigger happy with it when I get stuff I didn’t ask for.

The more specific you are the better you are. I once made the mistake of asking a very broad question and got hundreds of emails and then had to email people back asking for headshots.

Help a b2b writer is better in terms of quality answers from what I have heard (though most of the content I need help with is B2C), and I use it regularly as a source when there is something relevant.

Sourcebottle is another alternative (good for AU/UK markets as well as US),  though I use it less these days as I find for our business HARO is a better place to get the answers I am looking for.

text:
Hello all,

I head up content marketing at 15Five and I'm looking to build out my arsenal of experienced freelancer writers as we scale up our content production this year. (Check out <https://15five.com/blog|the blog> to see some of the content we put out)

Potential types of content include: blog writing (for SEO and thought leadership), eBooks, landing page copy, email copy.

Must have experience writing for B2B tech, major plus for experience writing for HR/HR tech, and/or writing about the workplace.

If this is you, or if you work in a similar space and have freelancers you'd recommend, please email me at <mailto:leah.bury@15five.com|leah.bury@15five.com>.

Include name, portfolio/work samples, and typical rates. Thank you!

text: <@U02G1JY10HW> :hugging_face:
*Fellow freelancers!* Do any of you track your time to see how you're spending it? I was using Toggl for a while but not sure I saw much value behind doing so. I'd love to hear your thoughts!

elements.text: Fellow freelancers!
Do any of you track your time to see how you're spending it? I was using Toggl for a while but not sure I saw much value behind doing so. I'd love to hear your thoughts!

text:
Rolled out an email <@U02TQCETCT1>

Thanks for posting :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: Rolled out an email
Thanks for posting

text: Yes! I track everything in Freshbooks, including my admin time. I find two primary benefits: 1) It helps me understand how long certain kinds of writing projects take, so I can be confident in my pricing estimates; 2) it helps keep me focused and on-ask when I’m “on the clock” for specific projects

text: I use RescueTime because I don't actually have to "track" it. It does it in the background and then I can go and look back. It's not perfect, but pretty close. And since I can't remember to turn timers on/off so no other app works for me.

elements.text: I use RescueTime because I don't actually have to "track" it. It does it in the background and then I can go and look back. It's not perfect, but pretty close. And since I can't remember to turn timers on/off so no other app works for me.

text: I also do what <@U0211K6LSM9> does and put all my tracked time for RT into Freshbooks, including Admin, so I can see where time is going and what I'm making on projects.

elements.text: I also do what
does and put all my tracked time for RT into Freshbooks, including Admin, so I can see where time is going and what I'm making on projects.

text: I use Yoco Board. It integrates with Asana which I use for project management. I can track how much I spend writing, doing admin work and more

elements.text: I use Yoco Board. It integrates with Asana which I use for project management. I can track how much I spend writing, doing admin work and more

text:
Yes, religiously! I've used Toggl since I started freelancing.
I'm a bit of a people pleaser so find it helps to know when I've topped out at my agreed amount of retainer work for the month. If my retainer covers roughly 20 hours a month and we're climbing past 25, I know I can take a breather and rearrange some tasks to fall into the next month. Clients don't necessarily know this; it's just how I arrange my work internally.
I also track 'admin' time which covers invoicing, my own marketing, updating my website - all that jazz - just to see how much time I'm spending 'on' the business vs 'in' the business.
Also... trying to get better at taking the time to do deep work and not context-switching constantly, as illustrated by a typical day... :face_with_rolling_eyes: It's a work in progress!

elements.text:

text: Seeking a *fintech freelance writer/editor* with expertise of these areas: PSPs, banking in the eurozone, SEPA, digital wallets, ecommerce payments, BIC/IBAN/SWIFT, PSD2-3DS-SCA, BNPL, Klarna, and others. DM me, let’s talk rates and capacity, can keep you plenty busy between now and August.
